deliberation: Examined covenant formula 'I will be God ... they shall be My people.' This is a technical legal-religious formula, not a metaphor or simile; no other imagery or idiomatic proverb present.
Looked for imagery beyond the historical-exodus/allusion sense. Found one idiomatic grace-expression and one metaphorical use of 'rest' for secure settlement.

instances.english_text: found favor in the wilderness
ground: being pleasing to a superior and accepted
posture: positive evaluation of Israel despite danger
instances.explanation: The idiom 'find favor' uses the image of gaining favor in a superior’s eyes to express receiving divine grace, without an actual search.

instances.english_text: when Israel was marching homeward / going to find rest
target: Israel’s transition from danger to security
vehicle: coming to a place of rest
ground: end of wandering and threat, experience of relief and security
posture: portrays return as peaceful culmination of hardship
instances.explanation: Israel’s restoration is depicted as going to a 'resting place,' using physical rest as a metaphor for political and spiritual security.

deliberation: Considered temporal/spatial 'from afar'; main clear metaphor is drawing/attracting with חסד, using the verb 'to draw' in a non-literal sense.

instances.english_text: therefore I continue / I have drawn you with grace
ground: bringing someone into closer relationship and safety by one-sided effort
posture: emphasizes gentle, intentional attraction rather than coercion
instances.explanation: The verb 'to draw' is used metaphorically: God does not literally pull Israel with a rope, but graciously attracts and brings them back.

deliberation: Two distinct images: Israel as a 'maiden' and Israel being 'built.' Both are non-literal descriptions of the nation and its restoration.

instances.english_text: O Maiden Israel
ground: youth, vulnerability, potential, and capacity for joy
posture: tender, affectionate view of Israel, in need of care and with hopeful future
instances.explanation: The nation is personified and metaphorically portrayed as a young virgin, highlighting her vulnerability and future joy.

instances.english_text: I will build you again, and you shall be rebuilt
ground: creating stable structure after ruin; orderly re-establishment
posture: frames restoration as solid, lasting reconstruction
instances.explanation: Restoring Israel as a people is described as rebuilding a structure; the community is not literally a building.

deliberation: Planting vineyards and enjoying their fruit can be literal agricultural restoration; no obvious metaphor, proverb, or personification distinct from the concrete promise.
Watchmen calling people to go up to Zion can be taken literally as sentinels or leaders; no marked figurative construction, simile, or idiom beyond normal worship language.
Looked for metaphorical titles or idioms. The main figure is the use of 'Jacob' to stand for the whole people of Israel, a standard metonymy.

instances.english_text: Cry out in joy for Jacob
vehicle: the patriarch Jacob as a name
posture: invites praise for the whole people via their ancestor’s name
instances.explanation: The name 'Jacob' stands for the entire nation descended from him, a metonymy of ancestor for people.

deliberation: Considered whether the geography is literal; 'from the ends of the earth' is a stock hyperbolic idiom for extreme distance, not a precise cosmological statement.

instances.english_text: from the ends of the earth
ground: very far away, scattered to remote places
posture: underscores how far God’s regathering reaches
instances.explanation: The phrase 'ends of the earth' exaggerates to express great distance; it is an idiomatic hyperbole for far-flung exile.

deliberation: Noted journey imagery and kinship language. The clearest figures are (1) God as father and Ephraim as firstborn, and (2) the 'level road' and 'streams of water' standing for safe, beneficial conditions of return.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־הָיִיתִי לְיִשְׂרָאֵל לְאָב וְאֶפְרַיִם בְּכֹרִי הוּא
instances.english_text: For I am a Father to Israel, and Ephraim is My first-born
posture: underscores deep, privileged bond and parental compassion
instances.explanation: God is not literally Israel’s biological parent; the father–firstborn image conveys care, priority, and covenantal responsibility.

instances.hebrew_text: אוֹלִיכֵם אֶל־נַחֲלֵי מַיִם בְּדֶרֶךְ יָשָׁר לֹא יִכָּשְׁלוּ בָּהּ
instances.english_text: I will lead them to streams of water, by a level road where they will not stumble
target: conditions of the return from exile and ensuing life
vehicle: well-watered paths and smooth, straight roadways
ground: provision, refreshment, safety, absence of obstacles
posture: portrays restoration as safe, nourishing journey under divine care
instances.explanation: The return is pictured as guidance along smooth, watered paths; this imagery goes beyond a literal route to express security and abundance.

deliberation: The key figure is the explicit simile likening God’s care for Israel to a shepherd caring for his flock.

instances.english_text: and will guard them as a shepherd his flock
ground: constant oversight, guidance, protection from danger
posture: reassures exiles of intimate, attentive protection
instances.explanation: An explicit simile: God’s guarding of Israel is compared to a shepherd’s care for sheep.

deliberation: Redeeming from 'the hand' of one stronger uses 'hand' as a metonymy for power or control, not a literal physical hand.

instances.english_text: and redeem him from the hand of one too strong for him
target: Israel’s subjection to a stronger power
vehicle: the hand of a strong person
ground: ability to seize, control, and oppress
posture: stresses how complete the domination was and how decisive God’s deliverance is
instances.explanation: The oppressor’s 'hand' stands for his power and control over Israel, a common Hebrew metonymy.

deliberation: Several figures: (1) people 'streaming' to God’s goodness, using a river-verb, (2) explicit simile 'their soul like a watered garden', and (3) 'they shall not again sorrow' as an idealizing hyperbole.

instances.english_text: and they shall stream to GOD’s goodness
target: the movement of people toward God’s beneficence
ground: continuous, eager, collective movement toward a source
posture: pictures their eagerness and abundance of movement toward blessing
instances.explanation: The verb 'to stream' is used figuratively of people moving like a river toward God’s goodness.

instances.english_text: their soul shall be like a watered garden
target: their inner life and overall well-being
posture: celebrates the fullness and stability of their future condition
instances.explanation: A simile explicitly likens their inner condition to a lush, irrigated garden, highlighting flourishing and satisfaction.

instances.english_text: and they shall never again languish
target: frequency of sorrow in restored times
ground: promise of radically reduced suffering, expressed as total elimination
posture: reassures by overstating the end of sorrow in absolute terms
instances.explanation: The claim that they will 'never again' languish functions as prophetic hyperbole, an idealized picture of future joy.

deliberation: Main figure is God 'turning' mourning into joy—transforming one emotional state into another as if it were a substance that can be changed.

instances.english_text: I will turn their mourning into joy
target: the people’s emotional and existential condition
ground: complete reversal from grief to gladness
posture: stresses radical, divinely effected reversal of fortune
instances.explanation: Mourning and joy are treated as convertible entities that God can 'turn' one into the other, a metaphor for total emotional reversal.

deliberation: Food/fat imagery is applied to 'soul' and to enjoying God’s 'goodness'; this uses satiation as a metaphor for full enjoyment of divine blessing.

instances.english_text: I will satiate the soul of the priests with fatness
target: inner satisfaction of priests with God’s provision
vehicle: being filled with rich fat food
posture: underscores lavish sufficiency of God’s provision
instances.explanation: The priests’ 'soul' is not literally filled with fat; physical satiation with rich food images their complete satisfaction.

deliberation: The whole scene is a poetic figure: ancestral Rachel, long dead, is pictured as weeping over exiled descendants; she stands for the nation/mothers of Israel.

instances.english_text: Rachel weeping for her children
target: the bereaved people of Israel, especially the northern tribes and their mothers
vehicle: Rachel, the matriarch, as a grieving mother
ground: deep maternal grief over loss of offspring, solidarity of ancestor with descendants
posture: laments the tragedy of exile with poignant maternal imagery
instances.explanation: Rachel, long dead, is personified and used metonymically as the mother of the northern tribes, weeping for exiled 'children.'

deliberation: Speech continues addressing the symbolic mother-figure introduced in v.15. The reference to 'your voice' and 'your eyes' presupposes the personified Rachel/Zion; that personification is still operative.

instances.english_text: Restrain your voice from weeping, and your eyes from tears
target: the grieving community of Israel represented as a woman/mother
vehicle: a woman’s weeping voice and tear-filled eyes
ground: visible and audible expressions of grief
posture: God now comforts and gently restrains the symbolic grieving mother
instances.explanation: The addressee’s 'voice' and 'eyes' belong to the already personified figure (Rachel/Zion) who represents Israel’s grief.

deliberation: Hope for the future and children’s return are straightforward promises of restoration without marked figurative imagery or idiom distinct from literal speech.
Two figures: (1) Ephraim as a name for the northern kingdom (metonymy), and (2) an explicit simile comparing Ephraim’s untrained state to a calf that has not been broken.

instances.english_text: Ephraim (as used here for the people)
ground: prominent tribe standing for the whole region/people
posture: individualizes the nation’s voice in a representative figure
instances.explanation: The name 'Ephraim' stands for the northern Israelites, a metonymy of prominent tribal ancestor/region for the whole people.

instances.english_text: like a calf that has not been broken (not trained)
target: Ephraim’s undisciplined, resistant character before repentance
ground: stubbornness, wildness, need for training and discipline
posture: acknowledges prior resistance to God’s discipline
instances.explanation: An explicit simile compares Ephraim to an untrained calf to express stubborn, undisciplined behavior.

deliberation: Gestures like 'striking my thigh' are literal signs of remorse; the more conceptual figure is 'I bore the reproach of my youth,' treating disgrace as something carried.

instances.english_text: for I bear the disgrace of my youth
target: ongoing consequences and memory of youthful sin
ground: shame as a weight one carries over time
posture: expresses deep, enduring sense of guilt
instances.explanation: Disgrace is conceptualized as a burden that can be 'borne,' an idiomatic metaphor for lasting shame.

deliberation: Several rich images: (1) Ephraim as a 'dear son' and 'child of delights'—kinship metaphor; (2) God’s 'inner parts' stirred for him—an anthropopathic image of compassion.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲבֵן יַקִּיר לִי אֶפְרַיִם אִם יֶלֶד שַׁעֲשֻׁעִים
instances.english_text: Is Ephraim a dear son to Me? Is he a child of delights?
ground: deep affection, special status, tender care
posture: emphasizes God’s enduring fondness despite discipline
instances.explanation: God speaks of Ephraim as a dear, delight-giving son; this familial language is metaphorical of divine–people relations, with Ephraim again metonymic for the people.

instances.english_text: Therefore My inward parts yearn for him
posture: anthropopathically portrays divine compassion in vivid bodily terms
instances.explanation: God’s compassion is pictured as churning in the 'inner parts,' a human bodily metaphor applied to God.

deliberation: Found two figures: Israel as 'Maiden' (personified nation) and 'set your heart on the highway,' using 'heart' for focused attention and internal orientation toward the way home.

instances.english_text: Return, O Maiden Israel
ground: youthfulness, purity (ideally), vulnerability, capacity for renewal
posture: invites the nation as a beloved but wayward young woman to return
instances.explanation: Israel is again personified as a virgin/maiden, a metaphor emphasizing relational and emotional aspects of return.

instances.english_text: Set your heart toward the highway, the road you traveled
target: Israel’s intentional orientation toward the path of return
vehicle: directing the heart toward a road
internal organ as seat of focus
ground: concentrated attention and determination fixed on a way back
posture: calls for deliberate, heartfelt commitment to the route of return
instances.explanation: The 'heart' stands for inner attention and will, metaphorically directed toward a 'highway' of return.

deliberation: Identified (1) Israel as 'rebellious daughter' (personified metaphor), and (2) the enigmatic saying 'a woman surrounds a man' as a symbolic, likely metaphorical, picture of a role-reversal/new dynamic.

instances.english_text: O rebellious daughter
posture: rebukes but still addresses Israel in familial, intimate terms
instances.explanation: The nation is personified as a 'rebellious daughter,' highlighting covenant infidelity in familial imagery.

instances.english_text: a woman shall surround a man
target: new pattern in Israel’s relationship with God (or social order)
ground: unexpected reversal, initiative from the weaker, protective or seeking embrace
posture: announces a surprising, restorative reconfiguration of relationships
instances.explanation: The 'new thing' is portrayed in terms of gender-role inversion; the woman’s surrounding of the man functions as a symbolic metaphor for an unexpected reversal in relational dynamics, commonly read as Israel seeking/embracing God.

deliberation: Two metaphorical designations: 'Abode of righteousness' and 'holy mountain' as titles for Jerusalem/Zion, imbuing place with moral and cultic qualities.

instances.english_text: Abode of righteousness
target: Jerusalem/Zion as restored community and city
ground: the city as a habitat where justice and right prevail
posture: recasts Jerusalem’s identity around righteousness rather than ruin
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is called the 'Abode of righteousness,' a metaphor that locates moral quality in the very character of the place.

instances.english_text: the holy mountain
target: Zion/Temple mount and its cultic community
ground: set-apartness, nearness to God, cultic centrality
posture: elevates the city’s stature as uniquely dedicated to YHWH
instances.explanation: Calling Jerusalem 'the holy mountain' is a metaphorical-cultic title, using the mountain image as a metonymy for the whole holy city and its temple.

deliberation: Description of habitation by farmers and shepherds is literal restoration imagery, without additional figurative overlay beyond normal usage.
Uses thirst and satiation of 'soul' as a metaphor for reviving the weary and filling the languishing.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי הִרְוֵיתִי נֶפֶשׁ עֲיֵפָה וְכָל־נֶפֶשׁ דָּאֲבָה מִלֵּאתִי
instances.english_text: For I will give the thirsty abundant drink, and satisfy all who languish
target: inner condition of the exhausted and sorrowful
vehicle: thirsty soul being given drink; being filled up
ground: renewal, relief, and satisfaction after depletion
posture: offers restorative, nurturing care to the broken
instances.explanation: Weary and languishing 'souls' are not literally thirsty; physical refreshment images spiritual and emotional restoration.

deliberation: The prophet’s awakening and finding his sleep pleasant is presented straightforwardly; no figurative idiom or imagery beyond literal experience.
Key metaphor: sowing the houses of Israel and Judah with 'seed of humans and animals'—applying agricultural sowing language to demographic restoration.

instances.hebrew_text: וְזָרַעְתִּי אֶת־בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל וְאֶת־בֵּית יְהוּדָה זֶרַע אָדָם וְזֶרַע בְּהֵמָה
instances.english_text: I will sow the House of Israel and the House of Judah with seed of people and seed of cattle
target: repopulation and renewal of Israel and Judah
ground: initiating growth leading to multiplication and fruitfulness
posture: depicts restoration as organic, divinely initiated growth
instances.explanation: People and animals are described as 'seed' that God will 'sow,' a metaphor for bringing about abundant life in the land.

deliberation: The sequence 'uproot, pull down, overthrow, destroy, build, plant' reprises Jeremiah’s commission imagery, applying agricultural and construction verbs to God’s dealings with the nation.

instances.hebrew_text: לִנְתֹשׁ וְלִנְתֹץ וְלַהֲרֹס וּלְהַאֲבִיד וּלְהָרֵעַ ... לִבְנוֹת וְלִנְטֹעַ
instances.english_text: to uproot and to pull down, to overthrow and to destroy and to bring disaster ... to build and to plant
target: God’s historical actions of judgment and restoration on Israel
vehicle: uprooting plants, demolishing buildings, then building and planting
ground: removal and demolition versus establishment and growth
posture: frames history as God’s purposeful renovating work on His people
instances.explanation: Israel’s downfall and renewal are portrayed in terms of plants and buildings being torn down or planted and built.

deliberation: The proverb about parents eating sour grapes and children’s teeth being set on edge is a figurative idiom where the grapes stand for sins and the teeth’s reaction for consequences.

instances.hebrew_text: אָבוֹת אָכְלוּ בֹסֶר וְשִׁנֵּי בָנִים תִּקְהֶינָה
instances.english_text: Parents have eaten sour grapes and children’s teeth are blunted/set on edge
vehicle: eating sour grapes affecting someone else’s teeth
ground: one party’s actions causing unpleasant consequences for another
posture: quotes a popular saying that the prophet then corrects
instances.explanation: The saying uses the image of sour grapes affecting others’ teeth to express the idea that children suffer for parents’ sins.

deliberation: Reuses the same sour-grape imagery, now applied individually; still a figurative idiom for sin and consequence.

instances.english_text: everyone who eats sour grapes, his teeth shall be blunted/set on edge
target: individual responsibility for sin and its consequences
vehicle: eating sour grapes affecting one’s own teeth
ground: the one who acts experiences the unpleasant consequence
direct cause-effect within the same person
posture: corrects the earlier proverb by insisting on individual responsibility
instances.explanation: Retains the sour-grape idiom as a metaphor: the one who 'eats' (sins) feels the 'teeth set on edge' (punishment).

deliberation: Declaration of a 'new covenant' uses covenant as a legal-religious term; no additional imagery or idiom is present here by itself.
Two clear anthropomorphic/relational metaphors: (1) God taking Israel 'by the hand' to lead them from Egypt, and (2) 'I was their husband' (or master), a marital metaphor for covenant.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּיוֹם הֶחֱזִיקִי בְיָדָם לְהוֹצִיאָם מֵאֶרֶץ מִצְרָיִם
instances.english_text: when I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt
target: God’s act of delivering Israel from Egypt
vehicle: an adult taking a child by the hand to lead
ground: tender guidance, protection, and initiative by the stronger party
posture: frames the exodus as parental, intimate guidance
instances.explanation: God did not literally hold physical hands; the exodus is pictured via the metaphor of a caregiver leading a child by the hand.

instances.english_text: though I espoused them / I was their husband
target: covenant relationship between God and Israel
ground: exclusive commitment, intimacy, faithfulness, and rightful expectations
posture: underscores Israel’s unfaithfulness as marital betrayal
instances.explanation: God’s covenant with Israel is depicted as a marriage in which God is the husband and Israel the spouse.

deliberation: The central metaphor is God putting Torah 'within them' and 'writing it on their hearts'—treating the heart as a tablet inscribed with teaching.

instances.english_text: I will put My Teaching within them and inscribe it upon their hearts
target: internalization of God’s will in the people
vehicle: placing and writing on an inner tablet (heart)
ground: permanent, intimate, internal knowledge and inclination
from external law to inward desire
posture: promises profound inner change, not just external legislation
instances.explanation: The human heart is pictured as a surface on which God writes Torah, a metaphor for deeply internalized guidance.

deliberation: Two figures: (1) 'from least to greatest' as a merism for all people, and (2) 'I will remember their sins no more' where remembering/forgetting is used metaphorically for holding sins to account.

instances.english_text: from the least of them to the greatest of them
target: the entire spectrum of Israel’s population
vehicle: minors and great ones as endpoints
ground: inclusion of all intermediate members by naming extremes
posture: stresses universality of knowledge of God
instances.explanation: This is a merism: citing the smallest and the greatest to signify everyone in between as well.

instances.english_text: and their sins I will remember no more
target: God’s treatment of Israel’s past sins
ground: not bringing sins to mind equals not holding them against people
posture: assures complete forgiveness framed as divine 'forgetting'
instances.explanation: Divine remembering is metonymic for acting upon sins; saying God will 'not remember' is an idiomatic metaphor for full forgiveness.

deliberation: Lists God’s cosmic acts—giving sun, moon, stars, calming the sea—in essentially literal cosmological-theological language; no marked metaphor beyond standard descriptions of sea waves.
Conditional statement using literal 'laws' of celestial bodies; Israel as 'offspring' is literal lineage language here; no distinct figurative idiom beyond this.

The impossibility of measuring the heavens or searching out earth’s foundations operates as hyperbolic imagery to stress God’s unbreakable commitment; 'foundations of the earth' also functions as metaphorical cosmological language.

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־יִמַּדּוּ שָׁמַיִם מִלְמַעְלָה וְיֵחָקְרוּ מוֹסְדֵי־אֶרֶץ לְמָטָּה
instances.english_text: If the heavens above could be measured, and the foundations of the earth below could be fathomed
target: the (im)possibility of God rejecting all Israel
vehicle: measuring heavens and probing earth’s foundations
ground: these tasks are impossibly vast, so the condition is unreal
posture: emphasizes that God’s rejection is as impossible as fully measuring cosmos
instances.explanation: Uses hyperbolic cosmological imagery—the impossible measurement of heavens and earth—to assert that God will not reject Israel.

deliberation: City being rebuilt 'for YHWH' expresses dedication but is not figurative beyond normal cultic language; tower and gate are concrete landmarks.
The measuring line going out to named hills is technical building/topographic description, not metaphorical in context.
Topographic description is literal; the main figure is 'never again uprooted or overthrown,' using agricultural uprooting and military-toppling as metaphors for destruction.

instances.english_text: They shall never again be uprooted or overthrown
target: future security and permanence of the sanctified city/area
ground: removal from place and violent destruction as images of ending existence there
posture: assures everlasting stability and holiness for the area
instances.explanation: The community/territory is not literally a plant to uproot or a building to raze; these are metaphors for being destroyed or expelled.
